title: 107_hr708
content:
The "Gift of Life Congressional Medal Act of 2001" authorizes the creation of a bronze medal by the Secretary of the Treasury to honor organ donors and their families. Eligibility requirements are outlined in the Act. The "Gift of Life Congressional Medal Act of 2001" allows organ donors and their families to receive a medal. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will oversee the documentation process to determine eligibility for the medal. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct an investigation to determine eligibility for the medal described in section 2. SEC. 4. PRESENTATION. The Secretary of the Treasury delivers medals to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, who then directs the OPTN contractor to present the medals to eligible recipients, with a limitation of one medal per family member involved in organ donation. The OPTN contractor may present an additional medal to each organ donor or their family if more than one family member is an organ donor. SEC. 5 allows duplicates of the described medal to be provided to recipients under certain regulations. SEC. 6 states that the medals are national medals. SEC. 7 waives procurement regulations for goods or services needed for this Act. SEC. 8 allows for solicitation of donations. The Secretary of the Treasury can collect funds with the OPTN contractor to offset medal issuance costs. Funds received by the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network must be promptly paid to the Treasury. Only up to 5 percent of funds can be used for administrative costs. Amounts received by the Treasury go to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury deposits all funds received under subsection (b)(1) into the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund and charges the fund for all medal issuance expenditures. A one-time amount of up to $55,000 is provided to the OPTN contractor for start-up costs, to be repaid within 3 years. The Secretary ensures that medal issuance results in no net cost to the Government. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS.

    Defines "organ" as specified human organs excluding corneas and eyes, and "Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network" as established under section 372 of the Public Health Service Act.

SEC. 10. SUNSET PROVISION.

    The Act is effective for a 2-year period from the date of enactment.
